{{Infobox sports competition event | event = 2017 CrossFit Games | competition = | image = 2017CrossFitGamesLogo.png | alt = | caption = | venue = [[Alliant Energy Center]] | venues = | location = [[Madison, Wisconsin]] | date = | dates = August 3–6, 2017 | previous = [[2016 CrossFit Games|2016]] | next = [[2018 CrossFit Games|2018]] | champions = | men = [[Mathew Fraser]] | women = [[Tia-Clair Toomey]] | team = Wasatch CrossFit }}
The '''2017 CrossFit Games''' are the eleventh [[CrossFit Games]] and were held on August 3–6, 2017, at the [[Alliant Energy Center]] in [[Madison, Wisconsin]], United States.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rodio|first1=Michael|title=Why the CrossFit Games Are Moving to Madison, Wisconsin|url=http://www.mensfitness.com/life/entertainment/why-crossfit-games-are-moving-madison-wisconsin|work=Men's Fitness|date=November 22, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=GAMES GO TO MADISON|url=https://games.crossfit.com/announcement/9870|website=CrossFit.com|date=January 5, 2017}}</ref> This was the first Games held outside the state of [[California]]. It was also the first year for the Masters 35–39 division.
The men's competition was won by [[Mathew Fraser]], the women's by [[Tia-Clair Toomey]], and Wasatch CrossFit won the Affiliate Cup. Fraser won $309,000 for his efforts and Toomey won $298,000 for her title, as prize money includes both the $285,000 for winning and bonus money ($3,000 for winning, $2,000 for second, and $1,000 for third) in each event.{{cn|date=July 2018}} This was the first CrossFit Games in which a podium finisher in the Individual competition was disqualified for using illegal performance-enhancing substances when Ricky Garard tested positive after the Games were complete.<ref name="DISQUALIFIED"/> As the Games had already concluded, all his finishes were simply voided with all other competitors moving up one position in the final standings as the event points were not redistributed.
==Individual==
===Thursday, August 3, 2017===
====Event 1: Run Swim Run==== *1.5 mile run *500 meter swim *1.5 mile run Athletes ran to [[Lake Monona]] from the [[Alliant Energy Center]], swam around a set of buoys, and then back to the arena. The event was won by Brent Fikowski and [[Tia-Clair Toomey]].
====Event 2: Cyclocross==== *3 laps around a [[cyclocross]] course The event was held nearby in Quann Park and had bikes supplied by Wisconsin-based [[Trek Bicycle Corporation]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cxmagazine.com/interview-cyclocross-crossfit-games-2017-madison-wisconsin |title=INTERVIEW: HOW CYCLOCROSS BECAME A PART OF THE 2017 CROSSFIT GAMES |publisher=''Cyclocross Magazine'' |date=August 3, 2017}}</ref> The course's obstacles included logs, small wooden hurdles and a sand trap. The event was won by Ricky Garard*<ref name= Garard>Garard won this event prior to being disqualified. The points were not redistributed, the first place position for the event was voided, and no other event winner was named in his place.</ref> and Kristin Holte.
====Event 3: Amanda .45==== *13–11–9–7–5 repetitions of [[pull-up (exercise)#Variations|muscle-ups]] and [[Snatch (weightlifting)|squat snatches]] for time. Athletes performed 13 muscle-ups on [[gymnastic rings]] and then 13 snatches, followed by 11 muscle-ups and 11 snatches, etc. until finishing the sets of 5. This is a variation of the event "Amanda" introduced at the [[2010 CrossFit Games]] as a tribute to former Games athlete, Amanda Miller, who died in 2010 and was known for the pistol tattoos on her hips.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://blog.beyondthewhiteboard.com/2016/09/08/amanda-the-woman-the-wod/ |title=Amanda: The Woman & The WOD |work=Beyond the Whiteboard |date=September 8, 2016}}</ref> The event was won by Dakota Rager for the men and by Jamie Greene for the women.
===Friday, August 4, 2017=== ====Event 4: Sprint O-Course==== *[[Obstacle course]] race Competitors raced head-to-head in three rounds across an obstacle course consisting of a [[cargo net]] climb, wall climb, [[monkey bars]], log balances, and a [[Ladder#Flexible ladders|rope ladder]]. The event was won by Patrick Vellner and Tennil Reed-Beuerlein.
====Event 5: 1RM Snatch==== *1-rep max [[Snatch (weightlifting)|snatch]] The event was won by Garret Fisher with a 305-pound lift and Kara Webb with a 203-pound lift.
====Event 6: Triple-G Chipper==== *100 [[pull-up (exercise)|pull-ups]] *80 GHD [[sit-up]]s *60 alternating [[Squat (exercise)#Bodyweight|one-legged squats]] *40-calorie [[Indoor rower|row]] *20 [[dumbbell]] [[push press]] The event was a "chipper," a workout involving multiple exercises done sequentially without returning (as in "chipping away" at the number of repetitions) for the fastest time. After the 100 pull-ups, the competitors performed 80 sit-ups on a glute-hamstring developer (GHD), a piece of equipment where the feet lock in and the sit-up is performed at a greater range of motion. After the sit-ups, athletes performed 60 one-legged squats, also called [[Squat (exercise)#Bodyweight|"pistols"]], alternating the movement between each leg. The 40-calorie row was performed on a [[Concept2|Concept-2]] [[rowing machine]]. The dumbbells for the [[push press]] were 100-pounds for the men and 70-pounds for the women. The event was won by [[Mathew Fraser]] and Kara Webb.
====Event 7: Assault Banger==== *[[Indoor cycling|Assault AirBike]] for calories *20-foot Banger The competitors started on the Assault bike and the calories were 40 for men and 30 for women. After the bike, the athletes used a [[sledgehammer]] to hit a weighted block on a recessed track until it had moved 20 feet. The event was won by George Sanchez and [[Samantha Briggs]].
===Saturday, August 5, 2017=== ====Event 8: Strongman's Fear==== *Move a yoke, farmer's logs, and a sled across a field. Return down the field in a handstand walk Competitors had to move a series of [[Strength athletics|strongman]] elements; a [[yoke]] (500 pounds for men, 340 pounds for women), two [[Strength athletics#Common disciplines|farmer's logs]] (200 pounds each for men, 120 pounds each for women), and a sled (400 pounds for men, 310 pounds for women). The objects had to be taken halfway down the field (60 feet) and then the competitor returned using a handstand walk. Once all objects were at the halfway mark, the competitors took the objects to the end of the field, also returning to the middle of the field with a handstand walk. The objects could be moved in any order. Brent Fikowski won the event for the men and [[Katrín Davíðsdóttir|Katrin Tanja Davidsdottir]] for the women.
====Event 9: Muscle-up Clean Ladder==== *Eight rounds for time of: **4 [[pull-up (exercise)#Variations|bar muscle-ups]] **2 [[Clean and Jerk#Clean|cleans]] with ascending weight Competitors performed each round beginning with four muscle-ups on a pull-up bar followed by two cleans. After each round the weight increased starting with 225 pounds for the men and 145 pounds for the women and ending with 350 and 235 pounds, respectively. Mathew Fraser won the event for the men and Tia-Clair Toomey won for the women.
====Event 10: Heavy 17.5==== *10 rounds for time of: **9 thrusters **35 double-unders A heavier version of a previous Open qualifier event in 2017. A [[Jumping rope#Double under|double-under]] is a jumping rope movement where the rope passes beneath the athlete twice per jump. A thruster in CrossFit is a combination of a [[front squat]] and [[push press]] in one continuous movement and the weights were 125 pounds for the men and 85 pounds for the women. Mathew Fraser won for the men and Kara Webb won for the women.
===Sunday, August 6, 2017===
====Event 11: Madison Triplet==== 5 rounds for time of: *450 meter run *7 [[Hay#Small bales|hay bale]] clean [[Burpee (exercise)|burpee]]s
Athletes ran around a 450-meter path outside of the stadium. In the stadium, there were five rows of hay bale walls. The athletes would enter the stadium and clean a [[sandbag]] up and toss it over the hay bale wall. They would then perform a burpee and then jump over the wall. The hay bale clean burpee would be performed seven times at the same hay bale wall before moving the sandbag to the next wall. After the sandbag is moved, the athletes ran back to the path to make another lap. The sandbags were 100 pounds for the men and 70 pounds for the women. The event was won by Ricky Garard*<ref name= Garard/> for the men and [[Samantha Briggs]] for the women.
====Event 12: 2223 Intervals==== 4 rounds of: *2 rope climbs *10/7-calorie SkiErg *Maximum repetitions of overhead squats with remaining time
This was an interval event with the first three rounds consisting of two minutes of work and then one minute of rest. The final round was three minutes of work to get as many overhead squats as possible or a total of 75 through all rounds for time. For each round, competitors started with two 20-foot rope climbs. After the rope climbs, the competitors pulled 10 calories for men and 7 calories for women on a [[Concept2#SkiErg|SkiErg]], a machine built by [[Concept2]] similar to their rowing machines but meant to simulate a [[Cross-country skiing (sport)|cross-country skiing]] motion. With the remaining time in each interval, they accumulated as many squats as they could with 155 pounds for the men and 105 pounds for the women. The event was won by Mathew Fraser and [[Katrín Tanja Davíðsdóttir]].
====Event 13: Fibonacci Final==== Men: *5 [[Parallette]] [[handstand push-up]]s *5 [[Deadlift]]s with two 203-pound [[kettlebell]]s *8 Parallette handstand push-ups *8 Kettlebell deadlifts *13 Parallette handstand push-ups *13 Kettlebell deadlifts *89-foot overhead lunge with two 53-pound kettlebells Women: *3 Parallette handstand push-ups *5 Deadlifts with two 124-pound kettlebells *5 Parallette handstand push-ups *8 Kettlebell deadlifts *8 Parallette handstand push-ups *13 Kettlebell deadlifts *89-foot overhead lunge with two 35-pound kettlebells
This event was won by Logan Collins and [[Sara Sigmundsdóttir|Ragnheiður Sara Sigmundsdottir]]. In the men's event, only Collins finished within the six-minute time cap with 2017 Games champion Mathew Fraser ending one lunge from the finish to take second in the event. On the women's side, Kara Webb had been in second-place overall below Tia-Clair Toomey. She edged out Toomey on the event by 0.19 seconds but did not overtake her in total points, finishing two points behind on the final standings.

{{use dmy dates|date=March 2016}} '''Accrington Stanley, Who Are They?''' is a slogan<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.skysports.com/opinion/story/0,25212,16711_6393275,00.html |title=Who are they? |publisher=Sky Sports |date=2010-09-22 |accessdate=2012-09-18}}</ref> that was used in an advert for milk by the [[Milk Marketing Board]] in the 1980s in the [[United Kingdom]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uktvadverts.com/Home/Search.aspx?advert=5632|title=Milk Delivery|work=UK TV Adverts|accessdate=23 September 2012}}</ref><ref name=eighty>{{cite web|last=Charles |first=Chris |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/a/accrington_stanley/5236018.stm |title=Accrington Stanley, who are they? |publisher=BBC Sport |date=2006-08-03 |accessdate=2012-09-18}}</ref> The advert starred [[Carl Rice]] and Kevin Staine.<ref>{{Citation | last = Shennan | first = Paddy | author-link = | date = 3 September 2013 | title = Boy from The White Stuff; Paddy Shennan talks to the actor who made his TV debut as a pint-sized Reds' fan | periodical = Liverpool Echo }}</ref>
== Advert == The advert features two young [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] fans with one telling the other that [[Ian Rush]] had told him that if he didn't drink milk, he would only be good enough to play for [[Accrington Stanley F.C.|Accrington Stanley]]. The other fan then said "Accrington Stanley, who are they?" with the response being "Exactly."<ref name=eighty /> According to Rice, [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] was originally going to be named. However, Tottenham objected, so Accrington Stanley were chosen instead<ref name=milkstar /> as they were a [[Non-League football|non-League]] team at the time<ref name=milkstar>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/lancashire/4788038.stm |title=Accrington thank milk advert star |publisher=BBC News |date=2006-03-09 |accessdate=2012-09-18}}</ref> and were seen to be a more obscure team.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bloxham |first=Andy |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/8579796/Writer-upsets-Accrington-with-description-of-unlovely-town.html |title=Writer upsets Accrington with description of 'unlovely' town |publisher=Telegraph |date= |accessdate=2012-09-18}}</ref>
It was also claimed by [[David Lloyd (cricketer)|David Lloyd]], a non executive director of Accrington Stanley, that the advert earned the club £10,000.<ref>{{cite web|author=Paul Newman |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2112308/David-Bumble-Lloyd-Talking-passionately-Accrington-Stanley.html |title=David 'Bumble' Lloyd: Talking passionately about Accrington Stanley |publisher=Daily Mail |date=2012-03-09 |accessdate=2012-09-18}}</ref>
== Reception == The advert was popular, and was continually shown for up to six years after it was originally made in 1989.<ref>{{cite web|author=Laura Sharpe |url=http://menmedia.co.uk/accringtonobserver/news/s/510311_milk_ad_kid_backs_reds |title=Milk ad kid backs Reds |publisher=Accrington Observer |date=2006-03-09 |accessdate=2012-09-18}}</ref> The phrase was seen to make Accrington Stanley the subject of jokes up to the present day.<ref name=tele/> However, residents of [[Accrington]] view the reference positively.<ref>{{cite web|last=Simpson |first=Mark |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/4889362.stm |title=The club that wouldn't die |publisher=BBC News |date=2006-04-07 |accessdate=2012-09-18}}</ref>
In March 2006, Rice was invited as the guest of honour to watch Accrington Stanley's match against [[Stevenage F.C.|Stevenage Borough]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metro.co.uk/showbiz/11148-accrington-ad-man-forgiven |title=Accrington ad man forgiven |publisher=Metro |date=2006-03-21 |accessdate=2012-09-18}}</ref> and was later invited to Accrington Stanley's last game of the season against [[Scarborough F.C.|Scarborough]], as they were promoted to [[Football League Two]].<ref name=tele>{{cite web|last=Bunyan |first=Nigel |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1515953/Accrington-Stanley-put-a-smile-on-the-face-of-football.html |title=Accrington Stanley put a smile on the face of football |publisher=Telegraph |date=2006-04-17 |accessdate=2012-09-18}}</ref> In September 2009, [[Sky Sports]] programme ''[[Soccer AM]]'' promoted Accrington Stanley's "Save Our Stanley" campaign because of the phrase, as they wanted to continue to use it to refer to the club when reading fixture lists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/socceram/story/0,21644,13871_5565549,00.html |title=Help save Accrington |publisher=Sky Sports |date=2009-09-17 |accessdate=2012-09-18}}</ref>
A [[shot-for-shot]] remake advertising [[Black Cow Vodka]], which is made from milk, began airing in September 2016, with a much older Rice reprising his role.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Polden|first1=Jake|title=Watch brilliant remake of famous "Accrington Stanley" milk advert|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/row-zed/accrington-stanley-who-they-watch-8873521|accessdate=6 June 2017|work=mirror|date=20 September 2016}}</ref> The advert was banned from airing in March 2017, due to concerns that it targeted children because of the connection to the original advert, and promoted excessive drinking.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Clarke|first1=Josie|title=Remember the 'Accrington Stanley?' milk ad? This sexy remake has been banned|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/remember-accrington-stanley-milk-advert-9986626|accessdate=6 June 2017|work=mirror|date=8 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title='Accrington Stanley' vodka parody ad banned|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-dorset-39203434|accessdate=6 June 2017|work=BBC News|date=8 March 2017}}</ref>

{{ infobox football league | logo = | pixels = | country = {{flagicon|BVI}} [[British Virgin Islands Football Association|British Virgin Islands]] | confed = [[CONCACAF]] | founded = 2009 | teams = [[#Current Teams - 2012–13|12]] | relegation = [[Tortola League]], [[Virgin Gorda League]] | levels = 1 | domest_cup = [[#Terry Evans Knockout Cup|Terry Evans Knockout Cup]]
[[#Wendol Williams Cup|Wendol Williams Cup]] | confed_cup = [[CFU Club Championship]]
[[CONCACAF Champions League]] | champions = [[One Love United FC]] | season = [[2018 BVIFA National Football League|2018]] | most successful club = [[Islanders FC]] (6) |website = [http://www.bvifootballassociation.com www.bvifootballassociation.com] | current = [[2018 BVIFA National Football League]] }} The '''BVIFA National Football League''' is the highest competitive football league in the [[British Virgin Islands]]. The league was founded in 2009 after the merger between the [[Tortola League]] and the [[Virgin Gorda League]]. In 2012 the league decided to split the teams into two groups, based on the position they finished in the standings at the end of the 2011-12 season.{{cite news|title= BVI Football Association introducing new National League format|url= http://bvinews.com/bvi/bvi-football-association-introducing-new-national-league-format/|accessdate=20 November 2012|newspaper=BVI News|date=12 September 2012}} The majority of matches in the league are held at the national stadium, the [[A.O. Shirley Recreation Ground]], based in [[Road Town]], [[Tortola]]. Matches are also held on the island of [[Virgin Gorda]]. ==Current Teams - 2015–16== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ===Group A=== *[[Islanders FC]] *[[Old Madrid FC|Old Madrid]] *[[Panthers FC (British Virgin Islands football club)|Panthers FC]] *Rebels FC {{col-2}} ===Group B=== *[[Sugar Boys]] *VG Ballstars *VG United *Wolues FC {{col-end}} ==Previous Winners== *2009–10: [[Islanders FC]] *[[2010–11 BVIFA National Football League|2010–11]]: [[Islanders FC]] *2011–12: [[Islanders FC]] *[[2012–13 BVIFA National Football League|2012–13]]: [[Islanders FC]][http://www.virginislandsnewsonline.com/en/news/islanders-beat-one-love-3-2-in-national-league-final Islanders beat One Love 3-2 in National League final] *[[2013–14 BVIFA National Football League|2013–14]]: [[Islanders FC]] *[[2014–15 BVIFA National Football League|2014–15]]: [[Islanders FC]] (9-a-side) *[[2015–16 BVIFA National Football League|2015–16]]: [[Sugar Boys]] (9-a-side) *[[2016–17 BVIFA National Football League|2016–17]]: [[Islanders FC]] *[[2018 BVIFA National Football League|2018]]: [[One Love United FC]] ==Domestic Cup Competitions== There are two domestic cup competitions played prior to the start of the league season, which were both founded in 2010. They are the '''Terry Evans Knockout Cup''', which is named after the former [[British Virgin Islands Football Association|BVIFA]] President and one of the forefathers of football in the [[British Virgin Islands]].{{cite news|title= Terry Evans Knockout Cup underway|url= http://bvinews.com/bvi/terry-evans-knockout-cup-underway/|accessdate=25 November 2012|newspaper=BVI News|date=13 April 2010}} And the '''Wendol Williams Cup''' (''also known as the '''Caribbean Cellars Wendol Williams Cup'''''), which is played in memory of former [[British Virgin Islands Football Association|BVIFA]] executive member Wendol Williams, who died aged 39 on 6 June 2010 on his way to the [[FIFA]] congress in [[South Africa]] ahead of the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]].{{cite news|title= Teams battle for Wendol Williams Cup|url= http://www.vistandpoint.com/latest-news/sports/5718-teams-battle-for-wendol-williams-cup.html|accessdate=25 November 2012|newspaper=VI Stand Point|date=9 August 2010}} {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ===Terry Evans Knockout Cup=== {| class="wikitable" |- !Year !Winner !Runner-Up |- |align=center|2010 |align="left"|[[Islanders FC]] |align="left"|Wolues FC |- |align=center|2011 |align="left"|VG Ballstars |align="left"|[[Islanders FC]] |- |align=center|2012 |align="left"|[[Islanders FC]] |align="left"|[[Sugar Boys]] |} {{col-2}} ===Wendol Williams Cup=== {| class="wikitable" |- !Year !Winner !Runner-Up |- |align=center|2010 |align="left"|[[One Love United FC]] |align="left"|[[Islanders FC]] |- |align=center|2011 |align="left"|VG Ballstars |align="left"|Panthers FC |- |align=center|2012 |align="left"|[[Sugar Boys]] |align="left"|[[Islanders FC]] |- |align=center|2013 |align="left"|[[Sugar Boys]] |align="left"|[[Islanders FC]] |} {{col-end}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.rsssf.com/tablesb/brmaagdchamp.html British Virgin Islands - List of Champions], RSSSF.com {{Football in the British Virgin Islands}} {{CONCACAF Leagues}} [[Category:Football competitions in the British Virgin Islands]] [[Category:Top level football leagues in the Caribbean]] [[Category:Sports leagues established in 2009]] [[Category:2009 establishments in the British Virgin Islands]] {{BritishVirginIslands-sport-stub}}

{{infobox country at games | CGA = BAN | CGAname = [[Bangladesh Olympic Association]] | games = Commonwealth Games | year = | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = {{url|nocban.com }} | location = | competitors = | sports = | flagbearer = | rank = 35 | gold = 2 | silver = 4 | bronze = 2 | officials = | app_begin_year = 1978 | app_end_year = | seealso = }} [[Bangladesh]] has competed at eight [[Commonwealth Games]], with the first coming in [[1978 Commonwealth Games|1978]]. They did not compete again until [[1990 Commonwealth Games|1990]], but have competed in every Games since. Bangladesh has won eight Commonwealth Games medals, all coming in shooting events. == Medals == {{See also|All-time medal tally of Commonwealth Games}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Games |width=60 bgcolor=gold | '''Gold''' |width=60 bgcolor=silver | '''Silver''' | width="60" bgcolor="#cc9966" | '''Bronze''' |width=60| '''Total''' |- |align=left| [[1978 Commonwealth Games|1978 Edmonton]] || 0 || 0 || 0 || 0 |- |align=left| [[1982 Commonwealth Games|1982 Brisbane]] || rowspan=2 colspan=4|''did not attend'' |- |align=left| [[1986 Commonwealth Games|1986 Edinburgh]] |- |align=left| [[1990 Commonwealth Games|1990 Auckland]] || 1 || 0 || 1 || 2 |- |align=left| [[1994 Commonwealth Games|1994 Victoria]] || 0 || 0 || 0 || 0 |- |align=left| [[1998 Commonwealth Games|1998 Kuala Lumpur]] || 0 || 0 || 0 || 0 |- |align=left| [[2002 Commonwealth Games|2002 Manchester]] || 1 || 0 || 0 || 1 |- |align=left| [[2006 Commonwealth Games|2006 Melbourne]] || 0 || 1 || 0 || 1 |- |align=left| [[2010 Commonwealth Games|2010 Delhi]] || 0 || 0 || 1 || 1 |- |align=left| [[2014 Commonwealth Games|2014 Glasgow]] || 0 || 1 || 0 || 1 |- |align=left| [[2018 Commonwealth Games|2018 Gold Coast]] || 0 || 2 || 0 || 2 |- !| Total || 2 || 4 || 2 || 8 |} == List of Medalists == [[Bangladesh|Bangladesh's]] most successful medallist at the [[Commonwealth Games]] was [[Asif Hossain Khan]] who earned himself one gold, one silver and one bronze. He also shares the most [[Commonwealth Games]] medals for [[Bangladesh]] with [[Abdullah Hel Baki]] with three medals each. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:95%" |- !Medal !Name !Games !Sport !Event |- |{{gold medal}} |[[Ateequr Rahman]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Delano-Hitch Stadium | nickname = The Ditch | image = [[Image:Delano-Hitch Stadium.jpg|300px]] | fullname = | location = [[Newburgh (city), New York|Newburgh]], [[New York (state)|NY]], United States | coordinates = {{coord|41|29|56|N|74|01|31|W}} | broke_ground = | built = 1926 | opened = 1926 | renovated = 1998 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = City of Newburgh | operator = | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = Newburgh Newts; Newburgh Hummingbirds, Newburgh Nighthawks, Newburgh Black Diamonds (former) | seating_capacity = 3,100 | dimensions = }} '''Delano-Hitch Stadium''' is a [[stadium]] in [[Newburgh (city), New York|Newburgh]], [[New York (state)|New York]]; it has a current capacity of 3,100.
==Early years== Baseball in Newburgh goes back to the 1860s: the '''Hudson River''' club played from 1863–67, compiling an 18-18 record against many of the top teams of the day. Several other short-lived pro teams called the city home before [[World War I]], including the '''Newburgh Taylor-Mades''' (aka '''Hill Climbers''' or '''Hillies''', Hudson River League, 1903–1907); the '''Newburgh Dutchmen''' (New York-New Jersey League, 1913) and the '''Newburgh Hillclimbers''' (Atlantic League, 1914).
In 1916, Mrs. Annie Delano Hitch (aunt of [[Franklin Delano Roosevelt]]) donated land to the City of Newburgh for a "driving park", later known as Delano-Hitch Recreation Park. The stadium was opened in 1926, and has been primarily used for [[baseball]]. Four professional teams have called Delano-Hitch home: the [[Newburgh Hummingbirds]] in 1946, the Newburgh Nighthawks in 1995-96, the [[Newburgh Black Diamonds]] in 1998, and the Newburgh Newts briefly in 2015.
{{See also|Newburgh Hummingbirds}}
==Later use== During the next half-century, the stadium was used by various amateur and semi-pro baseball teams, as well as by the semi-pro [[American football|football]] '''Newburgh Raiders''' from 1991-96. (Despite winning four Empire Football League championships, the EFL unanimously voted to boot Newburgh out in 1997 for a variety of reasons, including the fact that Delano-Hitch wasn't really suitable for football.)<ref>[http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20110517/SPORTS/105170328]</ref>
==1995-96 Newburgh Nighthawks== In 1995, owner Bill Cummings brought the '''Newburgh Nighthawks''' to town, as a franchise in the new [[Northeast League]] (now the [[Canadian American Association of Professional Baseball|Can-Am League]]). Despite decent attendance figures of about 1,000 per game, Cummings lost over $30,000 and sold the team to Jeff Kunion. The '96 Nighthawks won the NEL first half championship and played the [[Albany-Colonie Diamond Dogs]] for the league title, losing three games to one. The final game of the championship series proved to be the last Nighthawks' game ever, as Kunion, unsatisfied with the pace of stadium renovations, folded the team.
==1998 Newburgh Black Diamonds== After sitting empty in 1997, the stadium got a new team for 1998: the [[Atlantic League of Professional Baseball|Atlantic League]]'s '''[[Newburgh Black Diamonds]]'''. However, poor attendance and the league's displeasure with Delano-Hitch's condition sealed Newburgh's fate, despite $150,000 worth of renovations. Minutes before Newburgh's home opener, league president [[Bud Harrelson]] announced the Black Diamonds would return in 1999, but only if the team built a new stadium. Instead, the franchise was sent wandering for several years after a [[Lehigh Valley Multi-Purpose Sport Complex|proposed stadium]] in [[Easton, Pennsylvania]] was left unfinished after the builders went bankrupt; the team existed as the [[Road Warriors (Atlantic League)|Road Warriors]] through 2004, then again in 2006-07.
==21st century== Recently, Delano-Hitch has been used for amateur baseball, including high school ([[Newburgh Free Academy]]), college ([[Mount Saint Mary College]]), collegiate league ([[New York Generals (ACBL)|New York Generals]]) and [[American Legion]] ball. The financial downturn, however, has made it difficult for these teams to afford the rent on the stadium; since 2009, the ballpark has mostly sat empty, except for non-athletic gatherings. On August 7, 2010, Marcus Gill Ministries held a crusade, "Unity Fest with Minister Marcus Gill". About 150 people attended the crusade, held to encourage the community to pray for peace and to end crime in Newburgh.<ref>{{cite news|title=Unity Fest|url=http://hudsonvalley.ynn.com/content/512740/unityfest-offered-as-alternative-to-gangs/|accessdate=15 November 2011|newspaper=YNN|date=3 August 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Unity Fest Crusade with Marcus Gill|url=http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20100808/NEWS/8080332&cid=sitesearch|accessdate=15 November 2011|newspaper=The Record|date=7 August 2010}}</ref>
In 2011, the '''Newburgh Nuclears''' [[American Legion]] team returned to Delano-Hitch for a series of home games and tournaments, after raising $13,000 for the use of the facility.<ref>[http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20110517/SPORTS/105170328]</ref>
==Newburgh Newts== In 2015, Delano-Hitch was briefly the home of the '''Newburgh Newts''' of the [[North Country Baseball League]]. One of the new league's founding franchises, the Newts' first home game was played May 20 against the [[Watertown, New York|Watertown Bucks]], kicking off a planned 66-game schedule that was to run through early August.<ref>http://www.newtsbaseball.com/team-schedule.html</ref> After a series of tiny crowds of around twenty customers per game, the Newts were evicted from Delano-Hitch after three weeks, when their rent check bounced.<ref>http://www.recordonline.com/article/20150725/SPORTS/150729579</ref> The franchise continued to operate as a road team (apparently renamed the '''New York Newts''', according to the league website), one of two in the four-team circuit. Despite a slow start and being forced to play all of their contests on the road, the Newts finished 22-17, good enough for a first-place tie with the league's other road team, the Road City Explorers.
In early August, the Newts won the NCBL championship, sweeping Watertown in a two-game series. The Newts apparently folded after that, as they were not invited to join the four-team [[Empire Professional Baseball League]] in 2016.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.newburgh-ny.com/rec/delano-hitch.htm Official site] * [http://www.ballparkreviews.com/newburgh/newburgh.htm Delano-Hitch Stadium at Ballparkreviews.com] * [http://www.digitalballparks.com/Atlantic/DelanoHitch.html Delano-Hitch Stadium at Digitalballparks.com]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Dwyer Stadium | nickname = | image = | location = 299 Bank Street
[[Batavia, New York]] 14020 | coordinates = {{coord|43.009174|-78.178722|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = 1995 | opened = June 24, 1996http://www.toonathecat.net/ulb/news/html/teams/team_375_schedule_6.html | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Batavia, New York|City of Batavia]] | operator = [[Batavia Muckdogs|Genesee County Baseball Club]] | surface = Grass | construction_cost = $3 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|3000000|1996}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = Highland Associates{{cite web |title=American's for Disabilities Act Requirements|url=http://www.justice.gov/crt/foia/readingroom/frequent_requests/ada_tal/tal640a.txt|publisher=City of Batavia|date=July 14, 1995|accessdate=June 2, 2014}} | former_names = | tenants = [[Batavia Muckdogs]] ([[New York–Penn League|NYPL]]) (1996–present)
[[Scranton/Wilkes-Barre RailRiders|Empire State Yankees]] ([[International League|IL]]) (2012)
[[Genesee Community College|Genesee Community College Cougars]] ([[National Junior College Athletic Association|NJCAA]]) | seating_capacity = 2,600 | dimensions = Left Field: 325 feet
Center Field: 400 feet
Right Field: 325 feet }} '''Dwyer Stadium''' is a 2,600 capacity [[stadium]] in [[Batavia, New York]], situated in [[Genesee County, New York|Genesee County]]. Dwyer opened in 1996 replacing the original stadium that was built in 1937, the playing field at Dwyer is the original. The stadium is currently home to the [[Batavia Muckdogs]] - Class-A short season affiliate of the [[Miami Marlins]]; [[Genesee Community College]] Cougars - NJCAA; and high school teams including the Notre Dame of Batavia Fighting Irish and Batavia Blue Devils. ==History== The grandstand and surrounding structure of Dwyer Stadium may be new but the field and area hold over 70 years of professional baseball history. Originally built in 1939 the stadium underwent three names and stood until 1995 when being replaced by the new stadium, keeping the previous name. ===State Street Park (1939-WWII)=== State Street Park was built in 1939 and employed 17 local workers to construct. During the first season of play the stadium went unfinished and a snow fence had to be placed for each game to act as the outfield wall while chairs had to be borrowed from a local mortuary for seating. The works project continued through the first season but did not deter fans as 3,000, still a record for Batavia, attended the first game of professional baseball at State Street Park. ===MacArthur Stadium (WWII-1972)=== During World War II the name was changed to MacArthur Stadium after General Douglas MacArthur in an act of patriotism. ===Dwyer Stadium (Original - 1973-1995)=== Before the 1973 season the stadium found its final name, Dwyer Stadium, after Edward D. Dwyer, a long time team president that was instrumental in keeping the team in Batavia. The stadium was a wooden and covered grandstand that was famous in old time ballparks. ===Dwyer Stadium (1996–present)=== In 1995, it was officially announced Batavia would be getting a new $3 million stadium on the same location; the field would remain intact while the grandstand and seating would be torn down and replaced. Auburn and Batavia each got a stadium that was almost carbon copies of one another. The old Dwyer Stadium still has its place in the new stadium as the original Wall of Fame is still present behind the first base bleachers. ==Usage== Dwyer Stadium is primarily used for [[baseball]], though has also been home to area youth football as well throughout its history. Dwyer is the home field of the [[Batavia Muckdogs]] [[minor league]] baseball team, Short-Season Class-A affiliate of the [[Miami Marlins]] and also hosts college games during the spring and fall for the [[Genesee Community College]] Cougars as well as local high school games in the spring. ===Empire State Yankees=== During the 2012 season the Triple-A affiliate of the [[New York Yankees]], the [[Scranton Wilkes-Barre Yankees]], were scheduled to play seven games at Dwyer Stadium as the Yankees home stadium [[PNC Field]] in [[Moosic]], [[Pennsylvania]] underwent renovations. Before the scheduled games the [[New York Yankees]] made improvements to the infield and pitchers mound as well as the clubhouse. Due to weather conditions only four Triple-A games were played at Dwyer. ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.minorleaguebaseball.com/team1/page.jsp?ymd=20090106&content_id=492381&vkey=team1_t511&fext=.jsp&sid=t511 Batavia Muckdogs] *[http://www.littleballparks.com/Stadium/2001/Batavia/Batavia.htm Dwyer Stadium Views - ''Ball Parks of the Minor Leagues''] *[http://www.frontiernet.net/~rochballparks/batavia/batavia.htm Photographs of Dwyer Stadium - ''Rochester Area Ballparks''] {{NYPL Ballparks}} [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Genesee County, New York]] [[Category:Baseball venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:1996 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1996]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:High school baseball venues in the United States]]

revision.text:
A '''four-point field goal''' (also called a '''four-pointer''') is a [[Field goal (basketball)|field goal]] in a [[basketball]] game made from a part of the court designated for a four-point shot, the designated area is typically farther from the basket than the three-point arc. A successful attempt is worth four points, in contrast to the three points awarded for a shot beyond the three point line, two points awarded for field goals made within the three-point line and the one point for each made [[free throw]].
The four-pointer was introduced in competition by the [[Harlem Globetrotters]]. <ref>[https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/basketball/2016/09/22/harlem-globetrotters-basketball-four-point-line/90863242/ Harlem Globetrotters Add a Four-Point Line]</ref> The [[BIG3]] basketball league is the only current professional league that uses the four-point field goal.<ref>[https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nba/2017/06/26/big-3-ice-cube-mike-bibby-3-on-3-allen-iverson/429165001/ BIG3 Week 1 Recap]</ref> In BIG3, there are three distinct circles beyond the three-point arc designated as a four-point field goal area. A four-point field goal is attempted when a player shoots with any part of the player's body touching any part of the four-point circle. <ref>[https://big3.com/league-philosophy/rules-the-court BIG3 Rules]</ref>
==Footnotes== {{reflist|2}}
==Further reading==
* Mike Coppinger, [https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/basketball/2016/09/22/harlem-globetrotters-basketball-four-point-line/90863242/ "Going Deep: Harlem Globetrotters Add a Four Point Line,"] ''USA Today,'' Sept. 22, 2016. * Jordan Ellenberg and Josh Levin, [http://www.slate.com/articles/sports/sports_nut/2016/06/the_4_point_line_could_be_coming_to_the_nba_here_s_where_to_put_it.html "The 4 Point Line Could Be Coming to the NBA, Here's Where to Put It,"] Slate.com/ June 20, 2016. * Victor Mather, [https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/11/sports/basketball/new-three-on-three-league-has-a-4-point-shot-and-allen-iverson.html "New Three-on-Three League Has 4-Point Shot, Allen Iverson,"] ''New York Times,'' Jan. 11, 2017.

{{Infobox stadium | name = Galen Center | image = [[File:11-11-06-GalenCenter.jpg|220px|Galen Center]] | caption = The arena's north corner in November 2006 | location = 3400 S. Figueroa Street
[[Los Angeles]], [[California]] | coordinates = {{coord|34.021|-118.280|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = October 30, 2004{{cite web |title=USC Hoops, Volleyball Set to Open Long-Awaited Arena|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncb/news/story?id=2622204|work=[[ESPN]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=October 11, 2006|accessdate=November 13, 2013}} | built = | opened = October 12, 2006 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[University of Southern California]] | operator = [[University of Southern California]] | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]147 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|147000000|2006}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = [[HNTB]] | structural engineer = John A. Martin & Associates{{cite web |title=USC Galen Center|url=http://www.johnmartin.com/projects/sports--recreation/usc-galen-center.html|publisher=John A. Martin & Associates|accessdate=February 14, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402161611/http://www.johnmartin.com/projects/sports--recreation/usc-galen-center.html|archivedate=April 2, 2012}} | services engineer = M-E Engineers, Inc.{{cite web |title=USC Galen Event Center - Los Angeles, CA|url=http://www.me-engineers.com/projects/?office=global&category=college_and_minor_league&project=L32|publisher=M-E Engineers, Inc.|accessdate=February 14, 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425205612/http://www.me-engineers.com/projects/?office=global&category=college_and_minor_league|archivedate=April 25, 2012}} | general_contractor = [[A. James Clark|Clark Construction Group]]{{cite web |title=Galen Event Center|url=http://www.clarkconstruction.com/our-work/projects/galen-event-center|publisher=Clark Construction Group|accessdate=November 13, 2013}} | tenants = [[USC Trojans]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]])
(2006–present) | seating_capacity = [[Basketball]]: 10,258 | publictransit = {{LACMTA link logo}} [[Jefferson/USC (Los Angeles Metro station)|Jefferson/USC]] }} The '''Galen Center''' is a multipurpose indoor [[arena]] and athletic facility owned and operated by the [[University of Southern California]]. Located at the southeast corner of [[Jefferson Boulevard]] and [[Figueroa Street]] in the [[Exposition Park (Los Angeles)|Exposition Park]] area of [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], [[United States]], it is right across the street from the [[campus]] and near the [[Shrine Auditorium]]. The Galen Center is the home of the [[USC Trojans basketball (disambiguation)|USC Trojans basketball]] and [[USC Trojans women's volleyball|USC volleyball]]; in addition it hosts [[concert]]s, [[beauty contest|pageants]], theatrical performances, [[high school]] [[graduation]] ceremonies, [[California Interscholastic Federation|CIF]] championships and the [[Academic Decathlon]]. The annual [[Kids' Choice Awards]] were held here from 2011 to 2014, and returned in 2017. ==History== [[File:11-11-06-GalenCenter-inside.jpg|thumb|left|190px|Interior during an exhibition basketball game against [[Cal Poly Pomona Broncos|Cal Poly Pomona]]]] USC had planned to build an on-campus indoor arena for more than 100 years. Before the Galen Center, USC basketball had been played at a variety of locations, including the neighboring [[Shrine Auditorium]] stage, the old [[Pan-Pacific Auditorium]] in the [[Fairfax District, Los Angeles, California|Fairfax District]], and from 1959 onward at the [[Los Angeles Memorial Sports Arena]]. The final push to build the new facility began in 2002, when [[Louis Galen]], a successful banker and longtime Trojan fan, and his wife Helene donated $10 million to the new center immediately after USC football [[quarterback]] [[Carson Palmer]] won the 2002 [[Heisman Trophy]]. The Galens donated an additional $25 million to the project to have the building named after them and later upped their donation an additional $15 million to make sure that a connected practice facility would also bear their name, bringing the total donation to $50 million. Previously, the USC men's and women's basketball teams practiced at the smaller, on-campus North Gym. The Galen Center replaced the [[Los Angeles Memorial Sports Arena]] as the home for USC men's and women's basketball. Galen Center [[construction]] cost an estimated $147 million, which includes the arena, team offices, and a state-of-the-art practice facility. The largest [[tax]] revenue would be generated by the city of Los Angeles' 10% parking tax. Other sources of tax revenue will include [[sales tax]], utility users tax, business license tax, and income from [[advertising]]. In addition, two new [[parking structure]]s were built: a 1,200-space structure located between the [[Radisson Hotels|Radisson Hotel]] and the arena, with access from Flower Street, and a second structure at the southeast corner of Figueroa Street and Exposition Boulevard. The additional parking structures also increased the available parking for both the USC campus and the nearby [[Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum]]. [[File:11-11-06-UO-010t.jpg|thumb|left|190px|View of [[Downtown Los Angeles]] from the Galen Center's unique window]] [[File:GalenCenter1.jpg|thumb|right|190px|Building exterior]] The [[architect]]ural firm behind the design of the Galen Center is [[HNTB]]. Construction officially began on October 31, 2004, with a groundbreaking [[ceremony]] including [[Los Angeles City Council]] members [[Bernard Parks]] and [[Jan Perry]] along with Helene and Louis Galen, longtime USC fans for whom the facility is named. The first event, a women's volleyball game between USC and [[Stanford University]], took place on October 12, 2006. The first concert at the center was October 21, 2006 and featured Al Green. The first men's basketball was held on November 16 against the [[South Carolina Gamecocks men's basketball|University of South Carolina]].{{cite web |title=2006-07 USC Men's Basketball Schedule Announced|url=http://www.usctrojans.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/071406aao.html|publisher=USC Athletics|date=July 14, 2006|accessdate=November 13, 2013}}{{cite web |title=South Carolina 80, USC 74 (OT)|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=263200030|work=[[ESPN]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=November 16, 2006|accessdate=November 13, 2013}} The first sellout crowd was the men's basketball game against the [[UCLA Bruins men's basketball|UCLA Bruins]] on January 12, 2007 with an attendance of 9,682.{{cite web |title=No. 4 UCLA 65, Southern California 64|first=Beth|last=Harris|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/ncaab/recap?gid=200701130609|work=[[Yahoo! Sports]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=January 13, 2007|accessdate=January 13, 2007}} The highest attendance in the first year was for the [[Cal Bears]] men's basketball game on February 24, 2007 at 10,027.{{cite news |title=USC 84, California 66|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/scores107/107055/NCAAB703990.htm|newspaper=[[USA Today]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=February 25, 2007|accessdate=February 25, 2007}}{{cite web |title=Afflalo, No. 3 UCLA Rally, Avoid USC's Upset Bid|url=http://espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=270130030|work=[[ESPN]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=January 13, 2007|accessdate=November 13, 2013}} On January 31, 2008 the USC men's basketball game against the [[Arizona Wildcats men's basketball|Arizona Wildcats]] set the arena's attendance record with crowd of 10,258 in attendance.{{cite news |title=Trojans Are Banged Up in Loss|first=Ben|last=Bolch|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/feb/01/sports/sp-uschoops1|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=February 1, 2008|accessdate=November 13, 2013}} On May 10, 2014 the arena hosted a heavyweight title boxing fight between [[Chris Arreola]] and [[Bermane Stiverne]] for the vacant [[World Boxing Council]] Heavyweight Title. Stiverne won the title after a sixth-round [[knockout]] of Arreola, becoming the first Haitian-born boxer to win a world heavyweight championship, as well as the first out of the province of [[Quebec]], to win the [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] world heavyweight championship.{{cite web |url=http://www.fightnews.com/Boxing/stiverne-represent-country-born-haiti-quebec-also-love-united-states-276004 |title=Stiverne: I represent the country I was born in, Haiti, and then Quebec, but I also love the United States |author=Fight News editor |date=12 January 2015 |accessdate=11 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150411111847/http://www.fightnews.com/Boxing/stiverne-represent-country-born-haiti-quebec-also-love-united-states-276004 |archivedate=11 April 2015 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/boxing/story/_/id/10914967/bermane-stiverne-drops-chris-arreola-wins-heavyweight-world-title |title=Bermane Stiverne drops Arreola |author=Dan, Rafael |publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=12 May 2014| accessdate=11 April 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.torontosun.com/2014/05/15/bermane-stiverne-is-canadas-mystery-world-boxing-champ |title=Bermane Stiverne is Canada's mystery world boxing champ |author=Simmon, Stev |publisher=Toronto Sun |date=14 May 2014 |accessdate=10 April 2015}} ==Jim Sterkel Court== [[File:GalenCenter2.jpg|thumb|right|Interior, with premium seating on third Level]] The Galen Center's [[basketball court]] was named after former USC basketball player Jim Sterkel, who played for the [[USC Trojans|Trojans]] for two seasons in the 1950s, averaging 10 points a game. Two unique factors in the [[naming rights]] were the obscurity of the name choice and that the Sterkel family was not aware that the court was named after the late Jim Sterkel until after the facility had already opened.{{citation needed|date=March 2013}} B. Wayne Hughes, a longtime friend of Sterkel's made the $5 million donation under the agreement that his name never be revealed. In an interview with ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' columnist [[Bill Plaschke]], who tracked down Hughes but did not reveal his name, 'Anonymous' said that he grew up with Sterkel: both attended [[Mark Keppel High School]], both began at USC in 1955 and were roommates. 'Anonymous' later hired Sterkel and helped pay for his treatment when Sterkel was diagnosed with cancer. When the son of the anonymous donor contracted [[leukemia]], Sterkel wrote a poem and sealed it to be read only when the son had died. Sterkel later died in 1997, with the son dying two years later. Inspired by the poem and his friendship with Sterkel, 'Anonymous' made the donation and named the court after his friend, saying, "Some people don't deserve to be forgotten."{{cite news |title=Floored|first=Bill|last=Plaschke|author-link=Bill Plaschke|url=http://www.usc.edu/uscnews/stories/13228.html|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=November 5, 2006|accessdate=March 24, 2013}} ==Facility information== The facility is {{convert|255000|sqft|m2}}, with a {{convert|45000|sqft|m2}} pavilion, and has three practice courts and offices. The [[seating capacity]] is 10,258, and there are 22 [[Privacy|private]] [[suite (address)|suite]]s. The rights to purchase tickets for approximately ⅓ of the seats are being sold through lifetime [[personal seat license]]s, ranging from $2,500–$10,000 per seat. [[File:USC galen arena pano.jpg|thumb|none|400px|The full arena in concert configuration]] ==Events== * Taiwanese singer [[Jay Chou]] held his first concert on December 24, 2007 for his World Tour 2007. * The venue was the temporary home of the [[Nickelodeon]]'s [[Kids' Choice Awards]] while renovations occurred at UCLA's [[Pauley Pavilion]] beginning with the 2011 ceremony.{{cite web |title=Jack Black to Host Kids' Choice Awards for Third Time|first=Annie|last=Yuan|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jack-black-host-kids-choice-98913|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=February 11, 2011|accessdate=February 11, 2011}} The Galen hosted the KCA ceremonies from 2011 to 2014, then the network returned in 2017. * LAPD Cadets of Class 1-11 was held in May 2011. * A [[Los Angeles Lakers]] practice game was held on December 16, 2011. * Microsoft's [[Electronic Entertainment Expo|E3]] press conferences are held traditionally at the arena. * Preliminary auditions for [[The X Factor (U.S. season 3)|season 3 of The X-Factor]] were held at the arena on March 6, 2013. * The 2012 ''[[League of Legends]]'' [[Season 2 World Championship]] finals, and the 2013 World Championship semi-finals were held at Galen Center.{{cite web |title=League Of Legends Finals a Sell Out at Staples Center, North American Regionals Conclude|first=Jenna|last=Pitcher|url=http://www.polygon.com/2013/9/2/4685046/league-of-legends-finals-a-sell-out-at-staples-center|work=Polygon|date=September 2, 2013|accessdate=October 3, 2013}} * In 2011 and 2013, it played host to the Los Angeles audition stages of the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] singer search program ''[[The X Factor (U.S. TV series)|The X Factor]]''. * WBA Heavyweights [[Chris Arreola]] and [[Bermane Stiverne]] battled for the Championship Belt on May 10, 2014. * For the first time, the [[2015 Teen Choice Awards]] were held in the Galen Center on August 16, 2015.{{Cite web|url = http://www.galencenter.org/events/detail/teen-choice-awards|title = Galen Center :: Teen Choice Awards 2015|date = |accessdate = August 14, 2015|website = |publisher = Galen Center official website|last = |first = }} * [[Morrissey]] performed a special New Year's Eve concert on December 31, 2015. * Showtime Championship Boxing presented [[Jesus Cuellar]] vs [[Abner Mares]] on December 10, 2016 * Maze featuring [[Frankie Beverly]] performed an R&B concert on June 23, 2017. * During the [[2028 Summer Olympics]] the Galen Center will host [[Badminton]]. http://la24-prod.s3.amazonaws.com/assets/pdf/LA2024-canditature-part2_english.pdf * {| class="wikitable" |- ! Series Number ! Date |- |align=center| 1 | Sunday, May 8 and Monday, May 9, 2011 |- |align=center| 3 | Wednesday, July 10 to Friday, July 12, 2013 |} ==See also== *[[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== {{refbegin}} *{{cite news |title=Galen Center Time Flies When They Have Funds|first=Robyn|last=Norwood|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/oct/12/sports/sp-galen12|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=October 12, 2006|accessdate=November 13, 2013}} {{refend}} ==External links== *[http://web-app.usc.edu/venues/?id=106 Galen Center facilities page] {{University of Southern California}} {{USC Trojans men's basketball navbox}} {{USC Trojans women's basketball navbox}} {{Pacific-12 Conference basketball venue navbox}} {{California NCAA Division I college basketball venue navbox}} {{Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Awards}} {{Olympic venues badminton}} [[Category:Basketball venues in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Boxing venues in Los Angeles]] [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:College volleyball venues in the United States]] [[Category:USC Trojans basketball venues]] [[Category:USC Trojans men's volleyball]] [[Category:USC Trojans women's volleyball]] [[Category:Volleyball venues in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Venues of the 2028 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Olympic badminton venues]] [[Category:Olympic karate venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2006]] [[Category:2006 establishments in California]]

{{About|the 19th-century ice rink|museum in Argentina|Glaciarium (museum)}} [[File:GlaciariumPoster.jpg|thumb|An 1844 poster for the Glaciarium]]
The '''Glaciarium''' was the world's first mechanically frozen [[ice rink]].<ref name="harris">Martin C. Harris, ''Homes of British Ice Hockey''</ref> An item in the 8 June 1844 issue of Littell's Living Age headed "The Glaciarium" reports that "This establishment, which has been removed to Grafton street East' Tottenham-court-road [sic],was opened on Monday afternoon. The area of artificial ice is extremely convenient for such as may be desirous of engaging in the graceful and manly pastime of skating".<ref name="littell">Littell's Living Age, Volume 1, No. 4, p. 201</ref>
[[File:Glaciarium Ice Rink.jpg|thumb|Interior of the Glaciarium in 1876]] A later rink was opened by [[John Gamgee]] in a tent in a small building just off the [[Kings Road]] in [[Chelsea, London]], on 7 January 1876. In March, it moved to a permanent venue at 379 Kings Road, where a rink measuring 40 by 24 feet was established.<ref name="harris" />
The rink was based on a concrete surface, with layers of earth, cow hair and timber planks. Atop these were laid oval [[copper]] pipes carrying a solution of [[glycerine]] with [[ether]], [[nitrogen peroxide]] and [[water]]. The pipes were covered by water and the solution was pumped through, freezing the water into [[ice]]. Gamgee had discovered the process while attempting to develop a method to freeze meat for import from [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]], and had [[patented]] it as early as 1870.<ref name="harris" />
Gamgee operated the rink on a membership-only basis and attempted to attract a wealthy clientele, experienced in open-air [[ice skating]] during winters in the [[Alps]]. He installed an [[orchestra]] gallery, which could also be used by spectators, and decorated the walls with views of the [[Swiss Alps]].<ref name="harris" />
The rink initially proved a success, and Gamgee opened two further rinks later in the year: at [[Rusholme]] in [[Manchester]] and the "Floating Glaciarium" at [[Charing Cross]] in London, this last significantly larger at 115 by 25 feet. However, the process was expensive, and [[mist]]s rising from the ice deterred customers, forcing Gamgee to close the Glaciarium by the end of the year, and all his rinks had shut by mid-1878. However, the [[Southport Glaciarium]] opened in 1879, using Gamgee's method.<ref name="harris" />

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2014}} {{Use British English|date=November 2014}} {{refimprove|date=June 2011}} {{for|the nearby greyhound track also called Belle Vue|Belle Vue Stadium}} '''Hyde Road Stadium''' often referred to as Belle Vue was the home of the [[Belle Vue Aces]] [[motorcycle speedway|speedway]] team. The stadium's` capacity was 40,000 and it was built in 1928 and used until demolished in 1987. It was claimed, incorrectly, to have been the first purpose built speedway track in Britain.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Huggins |first1=Mike |last2=Williams |first2=Jack |title=Sport and the English, 1918-1939 |publisher=Routledge |page=67 |year=2005 |isbn=978-0415331845}}</ref> [[File:BelleVueSpeedway.jpg|thumb|right|Belle Vue Aces in 1963]]
==History== Part of the complex of buildings and attractions that formed [[Belle Vue Zoological Gardens]] the Hyde Road stadium was originally constructed in 1886 as an athletics ground. It was named after [[A57 road#Manchester–Sheffield|Hyde Road]], a road which begins at the east end of Ardwick Green South in [[Ardwick]] and runs east towards [[Hyde, Greater Manchester|Hyde]]. At the boundary between Gorton and [[Denton, Greater Manchester|Denton]] it continues as Manchester Road.<ref>''Geographia Manchester Colour Map''. London: Geographia, 1986 {{ISBN|0-09-218190-2}}</ref>
In 1928 the owners of the gardens decided to convert the stadium for use as a speedway venue. The opening speedway meeting here was staged on 23 March 1929, when Arthur Franklyn won the Golden Helmet. Following the announcement that Stuart Bamforth had sold the stadium for redevelopment, the last speedway meeting was staged on 1 November 1987, when a double header took place. Firstly, Belle Vue defeated the [[Coventry Bees]] in a replay of the League Cup before losing to the [[Cradley Heath Heathens]] in the final league match ever raced at Hyde Road.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bellevueaces.co/history_hyderd.aspx|title=History Hyde Road}}</ref> Speedway returned to Belle Vue Greyhound stadium and remained there.
Some of the more famous riders who rode at Hyde Road, either for international meetings, as a Belle Vue Ace, or as a visiting team rider include [[Individual Speedway World Championship|Speedway World Champions]] [[Jack Young (speedway rider)|Jack Young]], [[Peter Craven]], [[Ronnie Moore (speedway rider)|Ronnie Moore]], [[Ove Fundin]], [[Barry Briggs]], [[Ivan Mauger]], [[Ole Olsen (speedway rider)|Ole Olsen]], [[Peter Collins (speedway rider)|Peter Collins]], [[Anders Michanek]], [[Egon Müller]], [[Michael Lee (speedway rider)|Michael Lee]], [[Bruce Penhall]], [[Erik Gundersen]], and [[Hans Nielsen (speedway rider)|Hans Nielsen]].
The speedway at Hyde Road was {{convert|382|m|yd|abbr=off}} in length.
The site of the old Hyde Road stadium is now the site of the [[British Car Auctions|British Car Auctions Ltd]].
==Speedway World Finals== Hyde Road hosted the Final of the [[Speedway World Pairs Championship|World Pairs Championship]] in 1974 and 1977. ===World Pairs Championship=== * [[1974 Speedway World Pairs Championship|1974]] - {{flagicon|SWE}} [[Sweden]] ([[Anders Michanek]] / [[Sören Sjösten]]) - 28pts * [[1977 Speedway World Pairs Championship|1977]] - {{flagicon|ENG}} [[England]] ([[Peter Collins (speedway rider)|Peter Collins]] / [[Malcolm Simmons]]) - 28pts
==Other sports use== Several other sports used the ground including amateur [[soccer]] club, [[Manchester Central F.C.]], [[baseball]],<ref>{{cite book |last1=Huggins |first1=Mike |last2=Williams |first2=Jack |title=Sport and the English, 1918-1939 |publisher=Routledge |page=64 |year=2005 |isbn=978-0415331845}}</ref> and the [[rugby league]] where [[Broughton Rangers]] crossed from Salford to play at Belle Vue from 1933 until the club's demise in 1955 having renamed as Belle Vue Rangers in 1946.<ref>{{cite book |last=Cronin |first=Jill |last2=Rhodes |first2=Frank |title=Belle Vue |year=1999 |publisher=Tempus |isbn=0-7524-1571-9 |page=120}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://manchesterhistory.net/bellevue/stadium.html Bellevue Stadium]

{{Infobox Organization |name = Islamic Republic of Iran Basketball Federation |image = IranianSuperLeagueBasketball.png |size = 130px |caption = IRIBF logo |abbreviation = IRIBF |formation = 1945 |type = Sports organization |language = Persian |location = [[Tehran]], [[Iran]] |leader_title = President |leader_name = Ramin Tabatabaei |affiliations = [[International Basketball Federation|FIBA]], [[FIBA Asia]], [[National Olympic Committee of Islamic Republic of Iran|NOCI]] |website = [http://www.iranbasketball.org/ iranbasketball.org] }} The '''Islamic Republic of Iran Basketball Federation''' '''(I.R.I.B.F.)''' is the governing body for [[basketball]] in [[Iran]]. It was founded in 1945, and has been a member of [[FIBA]] since 1947. It is also a member of the [[FIBA Asia]]. The IRIBF is responsible for organizing the [[Iran national basketball team]]. َAvvalmarket {{Cite web|url=http://avvalmarket.ir/|title=اول مارکت {{!}} فروشگاه برنامه‌ های اندرویدی برای فارسی ‌زبانان|website=avvalmarket.ir|language=fa-IR|access-date=2018-10-14}}is sponsor of Team Melli Basketball. == Previous Presidents == Mahmoud Mashhoun (1979–1980)
Ali Moghaddasian (1980–1985)
Nasser Biglari (1985–1989)
Mahmoud Mashhoun (1989–1994)
Mehrdad Agin (1994–1997)
Ali Ghazanfari (1997–2002)
Mahmoud Mashhoun (2002–2017)
Ramin Tabatabaei (2018–Present) ==References== {{Sports governing bodies in Iran}} {{International basketball}} {{FIBA Asia associations}} [[Category:Sports governing bodies in Iran|Basketball federation]] [[Category:Basketball in Iran|National]] [[Category:Sports organisations established in 1945]] [[Category:Basketball governing bodies in Asia]] {{Iran-sport-stub}} {{Basketball-stub}}

'''Kallang Tennis Centre''' is a tennis court in [[Kallang]], [[Singapore]]. It is located along Stadium Boulevard, adjacent to the [[Kallang Field]], and is part of the Kallang Sports Centre. It is located just outside the central business district area.<ref name="kallangtennis">[https://web.archive.org/web/20120801185848/http://www.singapore2010.sg/public/sg2010/en/en_venues/en_compvenues/en_kallang_tennis_centre.html First youth Olympic Games: Kallang Tennis Centre]</ref>
==History== The Kallang Tennis Centre was opened as a community sports facility in March 1978. Since then, it has been a popular venue for tennis programmes and competitions, including hosting the local national schools’ tennis competitions. It is also the training venue for the national team and national youth teams.
The Kallang Tennis Centre is equipped with 14 courts.
==2010 Summer Youth Olympics== Kallang Tennis Centre was used as a competition venue for [[tennis]] during the [[2010 Summer Youth Olympics]].
Temporary seating stands for 2,000 were built around the main court for fans and the media during the Singapore 2010 Youth Olympic Games.<ref name="kallangtennis"/>

page.title: Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports

revision.text:
{{other uses|Ministry of Sports}} {{Use Indian English|date=October 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports |seal = Emblem of India.svg |seal_width = 70px |seal_caption = [[Emblem of India]] |nativename_a = |formed = |preceding1 = |jurisdiction = {{flagicon|India}}[[Republic of India]] |headquarters = Shastri Bhawan,
Dr. Rajendra Prasad Road, New Delhi-110001. |latd = |latm = |lats = |latNS = |longd = |longm = |longs = |longEW = |employees = |budget ={{INRConvert|1943.21|c}} (2017-18 est.){{cite web|url=http://indiabudget.gov.in/ub2017-18/eb/stat3a.pdf|format=PDF|title=EXPENDITURE OF MINISTRIES AND DEPARTMENTS|website=Indiabudget.gov.in|accessdate=15 September 2018}} |minister1_name = [[Rajyavardhan Singh Rathore]] |minister1_pfo = [[Minister of State]] (Independent Charge) |chief1_name =Amarendra Kumar Dubey, [[Indian Administrative Service|IAS]] |chief1_position =Youth Affairs Secretary |chief2_name =[[Rahul Bhatnagar]], [[Indian Administrative Service|IAS]] |chief2_position =Sports Secretary |child1_agency = [[Sports Authority of India]] |child2_agency = |child3_agency = |child4_agency = |child5_agency = |keydocument1 = |keydocument2 = |website = {{URL|yas.nic.in}} |logo=|chief3_name=|chief3_position=|chief4_name=|chief4_position=|chief5_name=|chief5_position=|chief6_name=|chief6_position=|chief7_name=|chief7_position=|chief8_name=|chief8_position=|chief9_name=|chief9_position=|parent_department=}} The '''Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports''' is a branch of the [[Government of India]], which administers Department of youth affairs and Department of Sports in India. [[Rajyavardhan Singh Rathore]] is the current [[Minister of Youth Affairs and Sports (India)|Minister of Youth Affairs and Sports]], who is in the capacity of [[Minister of State]] (Independent Charge).{{cite web | title = Minister of Youth Affairs and Sports |publisher= Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports | url = http://yas.nic.in| accessdate = 2014-08-13 }}{{citation |title=Portfolio of Modi government ministers: Vijay Goel appointed as the new Sports Minister |url=http://www.financialexpress.com/article/india-news/modi-cabinet-reshuffle-2016-vijay-goel-takes-oath-as-mos/307157 |work=[[The Financial Express (India)|The Financial Express]] |date=5 July 2016 }} The ministry also gives the annual National Sports awards in various categories, including the [[Arjuna Award]] and [[Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna| Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna award]]s.{{cite web | title = 2013 Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna and Arjuna Awards|publisher= Press Information Bureau, Ministry of Youth Affairs & Sports| url = http://pib.nic.in/newsite/erelease.aspx?relid=98548 |date=22 August 2013| accessdate = 2014-08-04 }} ==History== The Ministry was set up as the Department of Sports at the time of organisation of [[1982 Asian Games]] New Delhi. Its name was changed to the Department of Youth Affairs & Sports during celebration of the [[International Youth Year]], 1985. It became a separate Ministry on 27 May 2000. Subsequently, In 2008, the Ministry has been bifurcated into Department of Youth Affairs and Department of Sports under two separate [[Departmental secretary|Secretaries]].{{cite web | title = Introduction |publisher= Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports | url = http://yas.nic.in/en/yas2/introduction | accessdate = 2014-08-13 }} ==Department of Youth Affairs== Unlike the sports department, many of the functions of the department are related to other ministries, like Ministry of Education, Employment & Training, Health and Family Welfare thus it functions largely as a facilitator for youth building. It gives two awards, Tenzing Norgay National Adventure Award and Indira Gandhi NSS Award.{{cite web | title = Awards | publisher=Department of Youth Affairs| url = http://yas.nic.in/en/yas1/awards | accessdate = 2014-08-13 }} ===Definition of Youth=== The [[United Nations]] defines "Youth" as 15–24 years{{cite web | title = Youth |publisher=UNESCO| url = http://www.unesco.org/new/en/social-and-human-sciences/themes/youth/ | accessdate = 2014-08-13 }} and in the Commonwealth, it is 15–29 years. In order to use a definition more in line with these international standards, the Draft NYP 2012 changes the definition from 13–35 years to 16–30 years.{{cite web | title = Draft National Youth Policy 2012 seeks a shift in youth age bracket|publisher= Indian Express| url = http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/draft-national-youth-policy-2012-seeks-a-shift-in-youth-age-bracket/1073409/0 |author=Prasad Joshi|date= 13 February 2013 |accessdate = 2014-08-13 }} The draft NYP 2012 plans to divide the age bracket of 16–30 years into three groups.{{cite web | title = Draft policy redefines 16-30 age group as youth | url = http://www.deccanherald.com/content/253648/draft-policy-redefines-16-30.html |publisher=Deccan Herald|date=31 May 2012| accessdate = 2014-08-13 }} ===Organisations=== * [[Nehru Yuva Kendra Sangathan]] {{cite web | title = Nehru Yuva Kendra Sangathan |publisher= National Portal of India | url = http://india.gov.in/official-website-nehru-yuva-kendra-sangathan | accessdate = 2014-08-13 }} * Rajiv Gandhi National Institute of Youth Development{{cite web | title = About RGNIYD |publisher= Rajiv Gandhi National Institute of Youth Development | url = http://www.rgniyd.gov.in/content/about-rgniyd | accessdate = 2014-08-13}} ===Programmes === * Rashtriya Yuva Sashaktikaran Karyakram: Merge of schemes (National Youth Corps, Youth Hostels etc.) * National Programme for Youth and Adolescent Development (NPYAD): introduced 2008-09{{cite web|url=http://pib.nic.in/release/rel_print_page1.asp?relid=63581|title=Grants to NGOs|date=27 July 2010|publisher=Press Information Bureau, Government of India|accessdate=26 June 2014}} * [[National Service Scheme]] (NSS) * National Youth Corps *International Youth Exchange Program * [[National Youth Festival (India)|National Youth Festival]] {{cite web|title=About Department |publisher=Department of Youth Affairs |url=http://yas.nic.in/en/yas1/about-department |accessdate=2014-08-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140814155944/http://yas.nic.in/en/yas1/promotion-scouting-guiding |archivedate=14 August 2014 |df= }} * Urban Sports Infrastructure Scheme (USIS): a pilot project in 2010–11 to provide funding for infrastructure and improvements{{cite web|url=http://www.pib.nic.in/newsite/erelease.aspx?relid=86375|title=Urban Sports Infrastructure Scheme|date=21 August 2012|publisher=Government of India, Press Information Bureau|accessdate=26 June 2014}} * [[Panchayat Yuva Krida Aur Khel Abhiyan]]{{cite web|url=http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=93398|title=Objectives of PYKKA|date=11 March 2013|publisher=Government of India, Press Information Bureau|accessdate=26 June 2014}} * Promotion of Scouting & Guiding: The national headquarters of [[The Bharat Scouts and Guides]] (BSG) is recognised by the [[Government of India]] as the apex body in the field of [[Scouting and Guiding in India]].{{cite web|title=Promotion of Scouting & Guiding |publisher=Department of Youth Affairs, Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports |url=http://yas.nic.in/en/yas1/about-department |accessdate=2014-08-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140814155944/http://yas.nic.in/en/yas1/promotion-scouting-guiding |archivedate=14 August 2014 |df= }} * Youth Hostels ==Department of Sports== The department also gives away the National sports awards, including Special Awards to Medal Winners in International Sports Events, Maulana Abul Kalam Azad Trophy, [[Dhyanchand Award]] for Lifetime achievement in Sports and Games, [[Arjuna Award]], [[Dronacharya Award]], [[Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna]] Award and Rashtriya Khel Protsahan Puraskar.{{cite web|title=Awards |publisher=Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports |url=http://yas.nic.in/en/awards |accessdate=2014-08-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140814083416/http://yas.nic.in/en/awards |archivedate=14 August 2014 |df= }}{{cite web| title =National Sports Awards to be Presented on 31st August, 2013 |date=30 August 2013|publisher=[[Press Information Bureau]], Government of India| url = http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=98962 | accessdate = 2014-08-13 }}{{Cite web|url=http://www.cricketandwicket.com/|title=C&W: Cricket News|website=www.cricketandwicket.com|access-date=2017-06-05}}. They also helped in bringing the FIFA U-17 World cup to India. A huge part of it was played by the advisors to the Sports Ministry - Rahul Rana (Doon School) and Arjun Dewan (The Lawrence School). ===Organisations=== * [[Sports Authority of India]] {{cite web | title = Sports Authority of India, Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports| url = http://sportsauthorityofindia.nic.in/ | accessdate = 2014-08-13 }} * [[National Anti-Doping Agency|National Anti Doping Agency]] (NADA) {{cite web| title = NADA: National Anti Doping Agency | url = http://nada.nic.in/View/Homepage.aspx | accessdate = 2014-08-13 }} * [[Lakshmibai National University of Physical Education|Lakshmibai National Institute of Physical Education]] {{cite web |title=LNIPE Gwalior MP |url=http://lnipe.nic.in/public_html/thelnipe.html |accessdate=2014-08-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141020050724/http://lnipe.nic.in/public_html/thelnipe.html |archivedate=20 October 2014 |df= }} * [[National Dope Testing Laboratory]] (NDTL) {{cite web | title = National Dope Testing Laboratory (NDTL)| url = http://www.ndtlindia.com/ | accessdate = 2014-08-13 }} == Ministers of Youth Affairs and Sports== * [[Mamata Banerjee]] (1991 – 1993) * [[Uma Bharti]] (7 November 2000 – 25 August 2002) * [[Sunil Dutt]] (2004 – 2005){{cite web|url=http://164.100.24.208/ls/lsmember/biodata.asp?mpsno=476 |title=Current Lok Sabha Members Biographical Sketch |publisher=Web.archive.org |date= |accessdate=2013-07-12 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071112065955/http://164.100.24.208/ls/lsmember/biodata.asp?mpsno=476 |archivedate=12 November 2007 }} * [[Mani Shankar Aiyar]] (2005 – 2009) * [[M. S. Gill]] (28 May 2009 – 18 January 2011) * [[Ajay Maken]] (19 January 2011 – 28 October 2012) * [[Jitendra Singh (Congress politician)|Jitendra Singh]] (29 October 2012 – 25 May 2014) * [[Sarbananda Sonowal]] (20 May 2014 – 23 May 2016) * [[Jitendra Singh (BJP politician)|Jitendra Singh]] (23 May 2016 - 5 July 2016) * [[Vijay Goel]] (5 July 2016 – 2 September 2017) * [[Rajyavardhan Singh Rathore]] (3 September 2017 - present){{cite web|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/rajyavardhan-singh-rathore-sports-minister-vijay-goel/1/1039873.html|title=Rajyavardhan Singh Rathore first sportsperson to become sports minister|website=India Today|accessdate=15 September 2018}} ==See also== * [[Ministry of Sports]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{Official website|yas.nic.in}} {{Coord|28.615940|N|77.215747 | E|display=title}} {{Union ministries of India}} [[Category:Government ministries of India|Youth Affairs and Sports]] [[Category:Sports ministries|India, Youth Affairs and Sports]] [[Category:Sport in India|*]] [[Category:Children, young people and families ministries|India, Youth Affairs and Sports]] [[Category:Youth in India]] [[Category:Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports| ]] [[Category:Youth sport in India]]
